The new opera house, built on the site of the Bastille prison, had its grand opening today. The crowd roared with approval at the first Paris performance of ''Les Troyens,'' a seldom-performed work by Berlioz.

The 2,700-seat house was packed for what was to be 1 of 12 performances of the Bastille Opera's first season. The $385 million opera house was commissioned in 1982 by President Francois Mitterrand. Its predecessor, the green-roofed Opera Garnier, one of Paris's best-known landmarks, now turn to ballet.
Although the new opera house is dedicated to making lyric opera accessible to all, its first performance was a glittering affair, with patrons in dinner jackets and evening gowns.
A review of ''Les Troyens'' will appear tomorrow in The Times.
